subject: RE: [junit] Does this have a bad smell
msgSnippet: If unit testing prior to deployment is successful, then test code (assertions & invariant tests) placed in production code must be for diagnostic purposes in
messageBody:
If unit testing prior to deployment is successful, then test code
(assertions & invariant tests) placed in production code must be for
diagnostic purposes in anticipation of the possibility that unanticipated
environmental factors might cause faults.

In consideration of the article, I'd rather use a profiler or incorporate
the JPDA framework, since it allows me to arbitrarily instrument the class
under test any way I like. I don't know how much timing uncertainly
profilers or JPDA would add to the mix, so a simpler approach as in the
article might be best for specific threaded execution issues. Speaking of
timing, those Recorder methods should really be synchronized. Also, I
wouldn't want to depend on my (in)ability to type the correct method name in
the call to record(...) method since I would probably end up pasting it
incorrectly more often than not, so automatically capturing the method name
would be very helpful. Finally, it's a good idea to be able to turn off
accumulation of diagnostic information in production code in order to
prevent unnecessary memory usage.

> Well, yes, however to me it looks much more like a pattern for assertion
> testing than like a pattern for unit testing. If I had to unit test
> something like the controler, I would rather write own mock
> implementations
> of greeter and sender to test the controler: By doing so I will have no
> testing code in my production code. Does that seem too much of an
> overhead,
> or for what other reason is Eric Allen's approach more promising?
>
> Toyin
>
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: "Jason Rogers" <jason.rogers@...>
> To: <junit@yahoogroups.com>
> Sent: Tuesday, June 19, 2001 3:20 PM
> Subject: RE: [junit] Does this have a bad smell
>
>
> >
> > > I am a regular reader of Eric Allen's series at IBM
> > > devoloperWorks.
> > > In his newest article
> > > (http://www-106.ibm.com/developerworks/java/library/j-diag
> > > 0612.html) he
> > > intermingles test code with production code. In my
> > > opinion, this has a bad
> > > smell, but ... well, I am interested of your opinion as I
> > > am not to sure if
> > > I am right.
> >
> > Actually, I thought it was a *neat* idea, if needed. He points out to
> > places where the need for this might be apparent, you decide on
> the need.
> > Recorder is just a special case of a listener. You don't have to
> implement
> > it the way Eric did, I think his implementation is a case of
> DTSTTCPW for
> > his article. More than likely, if you wanted some kind of Recorder like
> > this you would have an update method on the observed classes that would
> > cause the observer(s) to update itself. If you wanted to get specific
> > information about the class that is updating (like the method name), you
> > could use the second parameter of the update method from the Observer
> > interface. Or if you have need of that param for something else, use
> double
> > dispatching to call back on the observable.
> >
> > In short, it's a bad smell if you don't need it (either through his
> > implementation or through your own).
> >
> > -Jason
